Consumer complaint narrative:
I am filing this complaint against TD Auto Finance for continued inaccurate and inconsistent credit reporting on my auto loan account, even after it was charged off. 

The company appears to have recently modified and re-aged the account. My previous report ( as of XX/XX/year> ) showed : Account charged off. {$20000.00} written off. {$20000.00} past due as of XX/XX/year>. 
Balance updated : XX/XX/year>. 

However, the same account was later changed to show : Account charged off. {$20000.00} written off. {$20000.00} past due as of XX/XX/year>. 
Balance updated : XX/XX/year>. 

There have been no payments or new activity since the charge-off in XX/XX/year>, so these updates are improper. Once an account is charged off, the balance and as of dates should remain fixed unless the consumer makes a payment. TD Auto Finance continues to update the balance monthly as if the account were still active, which is inaccurate and misleading.

This practice may violate the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA 623 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) and 623 ( a ) ( 5 ) ), which require furnishers to report complete and accurate information and prohibit re-aging of delinquent accounts. It also conflicts with Metro 2 reporting standards, which state that a charged-off account should reflect a static charge-off date and not report ongoing past due balances. 

I am requesting that the CFPB investigate TD Auto Finances credit reporting practices for this account and ensure the furnisher provides : The verified Date of First Delinquency ( DOFD ) The correct charge-off date An accurate, non-re-aged balance that reflects the final charge-off amount only TD Auto Finances continued updates after charge-off cause the account to appear more recent and more negative than it truly is, unfairly damaging my credit standing. I ask that these inaccurate updates be corrected or removed from all credit bureaus.

By permitting both Target and TD Bank to disregard proper fraud protocols, XXXX is failing to uphold its obligations to cardholders. 

I therefore demand immediate removal of all fraudulent charges, issuance of provisional credits, written confirmation that I am not liable for this debt, and assurance that no negative credit reporting will occur as a result of Targets failure to act. If these actions are not taken without delay, I will escalate this matter to the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, state and federal regulators, and I will pursue legal action against Target and TD Bank for violations of the FCBA and consumer protection laws.
